text: Multiyear study of the dependence of sea salt aerosol
label: BODY

text: on wind speed and sea ice conditions
label: BODY

text: in the coastal Arctic
label: BODY

text: N. W. May1, P. K. Quinn2, S. M. McNamara1, and K. A. Pratt1,3
label: BODY

text: 1Department of Chemistry, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA, 2Paciﬁc Marine Environmental Laboratory,
label: BODY

text: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Seattle, Washington, USA, 3Department of Earth and Environmental
label: BODY

text: Sciences, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA
label: BODY

text: Abstract Thinning of Arctic sea ice gives rise to ice fracturing and leads (areas of open water surrounded
label: BODY

text: by sea ice) that are a potential source of sea salt aerosol. Atmospheric particle inorganic ion concentrations,
label: BODY

text: local sea ice conditions, and meteorology at Barrow, AK, from 2006 to 2009, were combined to investigate
label: BODY

text: the dependence of submicron (aerodynamic diameter < 1 μm) and supermicron (aerodynamic diameter
label: BODY

text: 1–10 μm) sea saltmassconcentrationsonsea icecoverageandwind speed. Consistentwitha wind-dependent
label: BODY

text: source, supermicron sea salt mass concentrations increased in the presence of nearby leads and wind speeds
label: BODY

text: greater than 4 m s1. Increased supermicron and submicron sea salt chloride depletion was observed for
label: BODY

text: periods of low winds or a lack of nearby open water, consistent with transported sea salt inﬂuence. Sea salt
label: BODY

text: aerosol produced from leads has the potential to alter cloud formation, as well as the chemical composition
label: BODY

text: of the Arctic atmosphere and snowpack.
label: BODY

text: 1. Introduction
label: BODY

text: Rapid sea ice loss is dramatically changing the Arctic surface [Serreze and Stroeve, 2015]. Mean
label: BODY

text: September coverage of Arctic sea ice decreased by 13.3% decade1 for the period of 1979–2014
label: BODY

text: [Serreze and Stroeve, 2015], and complete summertime loss of sea ice is expected within 50 years
label: BODY

text: [Overland and Wang, 2013]. In the winter-spring, the Arctic is becoming increasingly dominated by
label: BODY

text: ﬁrst-year sea ice cover [Maslanik et al., 2011]. Thinner ﬁrst-year sea ice is less structurally stable and more
label: BODY

text: prone to fracturing, likely resulting in the formation of leads (transient areas of open water surrounded
label: BODY

text: by sea ice), as well as more pancake ice [Stroeve et al., 2012]. Increasing sea salt aerosol production is
label: BODY

text: expected from the newly exposed ocean surface [Browse et al., 2014; Struthers et al., 2011]. Sea ice loss
label: BODY

text: is also expected to increase the emissions of marine primary organic aerosol and dimethyl sulﬁde, as well as
label: BODY

text: lead to changes in aerosol processing and removal in the Arctic boundary layer through changing
label: BODY

text: meteorology [Browse et al., 2014].
label: BODY

text: Atmospheric aerosols represent the largest source of uncertainty in global radiative forcing predictions
label: BODY

text: [Boucher et al., 2013]. An increase in sea salt aerosol emissions will increase Arctic aerosol optical depth,
label: BODY

text: increasing the magnitude of aerosol direct radiative forcing (cooling) [Struthers et al., 2011]. Sea salt aerosols
label: BODY

text: can also indirectly alter radiative forcing by acting as cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) [Wise et al., 2009].
label: BODY

text: Simulations by Browse et al. [2014] suggested that the CCN response to increased sea salt aerosol from the
label: BODY

text: Arctic Ocean is weak due to efﬁcient scavenging of particles and decreased new particle formation from a
label: BODY

text: greater condensation sink. However, the predicted CCN response was spatially nonuniform, with coastal
label: BODY

text: Arctic regions predicted to have a larger CCN response than the central Arctic Ocean [Browse et al., 2014].
label: BODY

text: Further, deposition of sea salt aerosol to the snow surface contributes to springtime atmospheric reactive
label: BODY

text: bromine chemistry and ozone depletion [Pratt et al., 2013; Simpson et al., 2005]. However, due to limited
label: BODY

text: Arctic aerosol measurements, the contributions and radiative impacts of sea salt aerosol under changing
label: BODY

text: sea ice conditions are uncertain.
label: BODY

text: Under open ocean conditions, sea salt aerosol mass concentrations typically increase with increasing wind
label: BODY

text: speed [Lewis and Schwartz, 2004] and decreasing water temperature [Salter et al., 2015]. Airborne sea salt
label: BODY

text: aerosol particles are formed by two distinct processes when bubbles on the seawater surface burst
label: BODY

text: [Blanchard and Woodcock, 1957]. The fragmentation of the top of the bubble membrane produces ﬁlm drops.
label: BODY

text: After the bubble membrane top bursts, droplets of water are ﬂung upward from the bubble bottom,
label: BODY

text: MAY ET AL.
label: BODY

text: ARCTIC SEA SALT AEROSOL
label: BODY

label: H1

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: The Arctic: An AGU Joint
label: BODY

text: Special Collection
label: BODY

text: Key Points:
label: BODY

text: • Local sea ice coverage and wind
label: BODY

text: speed are controlling factors for Arctic
label: BODY

text: sea salt concentrations
label: BODY

text: • Sea salt aerosol is produced from sea
label: BODY

text: ice leads at wind speeds > 4 m/s
label: BODY

text: • The inﬂuence of long-range
label: BODY

text: transported sea salt aerosol was
label: BODY

text: greatest during periods of lower
label: BODY

text: winds and increased sea ice coverage
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Citation:
label: BODY

text: May, N. W., P. K. Quinn, S. M. McNamara,
label: BODY

text: and K. A. Pratt (2016), Multiyear study of
label: BODY

text: the dependence of sea salt aerosol on
label: BODY

text: wind speed and sea ice conditions in
label: BODY

text: the coastal Arctic, J. Geophys. Res.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: producing jet drops. Particles result from ﬁlm and jet drops after evaporation, with ﬁlm drops mainly resulting
label: BODY

text: in submicron particles and jet drops generally resulting in supermicron particles [O’Dowd et al., 1997]. Over
label: BODY

text: the open ocean, the bubble-bursting production of sea salt aerosol is driven by wind-induced wave breaking
label: BODY

text: that entrains air underneath the ocean surface. However, there is still uncertainty regarding the mechanism
label: BODY

text: of aerosol production from leads. Nilsson et al. [2001] and Leck et al. [2002] measured wind-dependent
label: BODY

text: number ﬂuxes of particles, likely produced through the bubble-bursting mechanism, from open leads at a
label: BODY

text: rate ~10 times less than the open ocean, which was attributed to the decreased fetch over the open leads.
label: BODY

text: However, Nilsson et al. [2001] found that an additional particle emission mechanism was needed to explain
label: BODY

text: the particle number ﬂuxes at low wind speeds. Studies conducted under lower wind speed conditions have
label: BODY

text: proposed emission mechanisms, including the transport of bubbles to the surface by increased turbulence
label: BODY

text: caused by supercooling conditions [Grammatika and Zimmerman, 2001], gas released from melting ice
label: BODY

text: [Leck and Bigg, 1999; Nilsson et al., 2001], phytoplankton respiration [Johnson and Wangersky, 1987], and a
label: BODY

text: surface heat ﬂux-driven mechanism [Norris et al., 2011].
label: BODY

text: Sea salt aerosol is a signiﬁcant contributor to Arctic particle mass [Quinn et al., 2002]. Given the impacts of sea
label: BODY

text: salt aerosol on climate and the changing sea ice surface, it is imperative to evaluate the contribution of sea
label: BODY

text: salt aerosol produced from leads. Previous Arctic spring [Radke et al., 1976; Scott and Levin, 1972] and summer
label: BODY

text: [Held et al., 2011a; Held et al., 2011b; Leck and Persson, 1996; Leck and Bigg, 1999; Leck and Svensson, 2015;
label: BODY

text: Leck et al., 2002; Nilsson et al., 2001] short-term intensive studies measured the direct ﬂux of particles from
label: BODY

text: leads over the pack ice. However, signiﬁcant uncertainty remains regarding the extent leads currently
label: BODY

text: inﬂuence Arctic particle mass concentrations over multiple seasons and at coastal locations. Therefore, to
label: BODY

text: build on previous work on the production of aerosols from leads and to probe the wind dependence of
label: BODY

text: sea salt aerosol production from Arctic leads across multiple seasons and years, we present an examination
label: BODY

text: of sea salt concentrations near Barrow, Alaska, under varying local sea ice and wind speed conditions from
label: BODY

text: April 2006 to December 2009.
label: BODY

text: 2. Methods
label: BODY

text: 2.1. Meteorology
label: BODY

text: Wind speed and wind direction data were available with 1 min resolution for the National Oceanic and
label: BODY

text: Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Barrow Observatory (71°32′30″N, 156°61′14″W) at 10 m above ground.
label: BODY

text: Given that wind speeds ≥4 m s1 over open ocean are typically associated with the formation of bubbles
label: BODY

text: responsible for sea salt aerosol production [Monahan and O’Muircheartaigh, 1986], wind speed data were
label: BODY

text: divided into three average wind speed categories: (1) “low” < 4 m s1, (2) “moderate” 4–7 m s1, and (3)
label: BODY

text: “high” >7 m s1. As there are no direct measurements of wind speed over the adjacent Arctic Ocean avail-
label: BODY

text: able, it is assumed that local measured wind speed is representative of the wind speed over the nearby
label: BODY

text: sea ice and open water. The local wind speeds observed in this study are consistent with previous obser-
label: BODY

text: vations of Arctic wind speeds over sea ice [Tjernström et al., 2012], with low or moderate wind speeds pre-
label: BODY

text: sent for 22% and 62% of supermicron, respectively, and 29% and 48%, respectively, of submicron particle
label: BODY

text: sampling periods.
label: BODY

text: 2.2. Sea Ice Radar
label: BODY

text: The coverage of local near-shore sea ice at Barrow, AK was determined by examination of radar backscatter
label: BODY

text: maps (http://seaice.alaska.edu/gi/data/barrow_radar) produced from a Furuno 10 kW, X-band marine radar,
label: BODY

text: which provides high spatial resolution sea ice imaging during both light and dark periods (Figure 1). The
label: BODY

text: radar operated atop a building in downtown Barrow (71°17′33″ N, 156°47′17″W) 22.5 m above sea level, with
label: BODY

text: a range of up to 11 km to the northwest [Druckenmiller et al., 2009; Eicken et al., 2011]. While the radar only
label: BODY

text: covered sea ice conditions to the northwest in this analysis, any lead activity observed within the 11 km range
label: BODY

text: analyzed in this study was assumed to reﬂect lead activity along the coast to the southwest and northeast, as
label: BODY

text: observed frequently by Mahoney et al. [2014]. Radar backscatter maps were manually analyzed to divide the
label: BODY

text: observed local sea surface into three categories: (1) full sea ice cover present, when local sea ice cover was
label: BODY

text: complete and no areas of exposed ocean surface were present; (2) leads present, when local sea ice cover
label: BODY

text: with areas of exposed ocean surface was present: and (3) open ocean, when no major local sea ice cover
label: BODY

text: was observed on the radar map (Figure 1).
label: BODY

text: Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres
label: BODY

text: MAY ET AL.
label: BODY

text: ARCTIC SEA SALT AEROSOL
label: BODY

text: 2.3. Aerosol Chemical Composition
label: BODY

text: Atmospheric particles were sampled at
label: BODY

text: the NOAA Barrow Observatory 10 m
label: BODY

text: above the surface from April 2006 to
label: BODY

text: December 2009. Real-time wind direc-
label: BODY

text: tion was used to sample only from the
label: BODY

text: clean air sector (0°–129°) to avoid inﬂu-
label: BODY

text: ence from local pollution [Quinn et al.,
label: BODY

text: 2002]. The Beaufort and Chukchi Seas
label: BODY

text: are 2–25 km upwind of the aerosol sam-
label: BODY

text: pling site in the clean air sector, so all air
label: BODY

text: sampled is assumed to be of direct mar-
label: BODY

text: ine origin. A Berner-type multijet cas-
label: BODY

text: cade impactor operating at a sample
label: BODY

text: ﬂow rate of 30 L min1 with 50% cut
label: BODY

text: points at aerodynamic diameters (D50)
label: BODY

text: of 10 μm and 1 μm was used to collect
label: BODY

text: particles
label: BODY

text: with
label: BODY

text: aerodynamic
label: BODY

text: dia-
label: BODY

text: meters < 1 μm (referred to as submi-
label: BODY

text: cron particles) and 1–10 μm (referred
label: BODY

text: to as supermicron particles). Particles
label: BODY

text: with diameters < 1 μm passed through
label: BODY

text: an impactor to a rotating ﬁlter carousel
label: BODY

text: housing eight Millipore Fluoropore ﬁl-
label: BODY

text: ters (1.0 mm pore size). For every revolu-
label: BODY

text: tion of the rotating submicron ﬁlter
label: BODY

text: carousel, seven ﬁlters were sampled
label: BODY

text: individually, with sampling time varying
label: BODY

text: depending on season and particle load-
label: BODY

text: ings, and one ﬁlter, exposed to ambient
label: BODY

text: air for 10 s, served as a blank. Particles
label: BODY

text: with aerodynamic diameters between
label: BODY

text: 1 and 10 μm were collected on Tedlar
label: BODY

text: ﬁlms over the course of one revolution
label: BODY

text: of the rotating submicron ﬁlter carousel,
label: BODY

text: with one additional ﬁlm collected as a
label: BODY

text: blank for every supermicron sample
label: BODY

text: Figure 1. Representative radar backscatter
label: BODY

text: maps of local near-shore sea surface at
label: BODY

text: Barrow, AK. The yellow arrow indicates
label: BODY

text: direction of north, the aerosol sampling
label: BODY

text: location is marked by a yellow circle, and the
label: BODY

text: radar backscatter location is marked with a
label: BODY

text: yellow square. Land is colored green, white is
label: BODY

text: indicative of sea ice, and black is shown for
label: BODY

text: open water. Sea ice conditions include (a) full
label: BODY

text: sea ice coverage, indicated by the full
label: BODY

text: coverage of the white signal indicative of sea
label: BODY

text: ice; (b) leads present, identiﬁed from the area
label: BODY

text: of dark signal in the upper left indicative of
label: BODY

text: open ocean present in the middle of the
label: BODY

text: white signal indicative of sea ice; and (c) open
label: BODY

text: ocean, identiﬁed from the full coverage of the
label: BODY

text: dark signal indicative of open ocean.
label: BODY

text: Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres
label: BODY

text: MAY ET AL.
label: BODY

text: ARCTIC SEA SALT AEROSOL
label: BODY

text: collected. To minimize bounce of large particles onto downstream submicron ﬁlters, a 12 mm grease cup
label: BODY

text: coated with silicone grease and a ﬁlm coated with silicone spray were placed on the 10 μm jet [Quinn
label: BODY

text: et al., 2002]. Sample air was heated to maintain a stable reference relative humidity (RH) of 40% despite
label: BODY

text: changes in ambient RH. The stable sampling RH allows for a constant instrumental size segregation, and
label: BODY

text: all measurements are reported at the reference RH [Quinn et al., 2002]. Submicron and supermicron particle
label: BODY

text: sampling periods ranged from 1 to 11 days and 5 to 35 days, respectively. After collection, sealed ﬁlters and
label: BODY

text: ﬁlms were shipped to the NOAA Paciﬁc Marine Environmental Laboratory for analysis.
label: BODY

text: For inorganic ion analysis, ﬁlters and ﬁlms were ﬁrst wetted with 1 mL of spectral grade methanol. Five milli-
label: BODY

text: liters of distilled deionized water was then added to the solution, and the samples were extracted by sonicat-
label: BODY

text: ing for 30 min. Concentrations of major cations (Na+, NH4
label: BODY

text: +, K+, Mg2+, and Ca2+) and anions (CH3SO3
label: BODY

text: Br, NO3
label: BODY

text: , SO4
label: BODY

text: 2, and C2O₄2) extracted from each submicron and supermicron particle sample were mea-
label: BODY

text: sured by ion chromatography [Quinn et al., 1998]. Details of the inlet, sampling procedures, and chemical ana-
label: BODY

text: lyses can be found in Delene and Ogren [2002] and Quinn et al. [2002]. Based on the aerosol sampling ﬂow rate
label: BODY

text: (30 L min1) and typical sampling time, the detection limits calculated as 2 times the standard deviation of
label: BODY

text: the blank for the major sea salt ions of interest, Na+ and Cl, were both 0.0002 μg m3. For periods that were
label: BODY

text: below the detection limit, a value of half the detection limit (0.0001 μg m3) was substituted for calculations.
label: BODY

text: Periods below the detection limit constituted 0% of supermicron and 12% submicron sampling periods for
label: BODY

text: Na+ and 3% of supermicron and 20% submicron sampling periods for Cl. Na+ mass concentration is a con-
label: BODY

text: servative tracer for sea salt mass [Legrand et al., 2016] and will be discussed henceforth in the place of sea salt
label: BODY

text: mass to avoid biases from varying chloride depletion. While sea spray aerosol is a complex mixture of inor-
label: BODY

text: ganic salts and organic compounds, the distribution of which alters the chemical and physical properties
label: BODY

text: of the particle, sea spray aerosol is primarily (>60%) composed of inorganic salt [Quinn et al., 2015]. All Na+
label: BODY

text: is assumed to be derived from seawater [Quinn et al., 2002], as Sirois and Barrie [1999] showed that the major-
label: BODY

text: ity of Na+ in the Arctic is associated with sea salt aerosol. Error was calculated as the standard error of the
label: BODY

text: mean and is not shown for periods when only one sampling period fell into the given sea surface and wind
label: BODY

text: speed category.
label: BODY

text: 3. Results and Discussion
label: BODY

text: 3.1. Sea Salt Mass Concentrations
label: BODY

text: A clear dependence of supermicron (1–10 μm) Na+ (sea salt) mass concentrations on the combination of local
label: BODY

text: sea ice coverage and wind speed was observed (Figure 2a). There was little difference in the supermicron Na+
label: BODY

text: mass concentrations observed for periods with no leads present and low (<4 m s1) (0.04 ± 0.01 μg m3) or
label: BODY

text: moderate (4–7 m s1) (0.03 μg m3) wind speeds compared to periods with leads and low wind speeds
label: BODY

text: (0.026 ± 0.009 μg m3). However, for periods characterized by moderate wind speeds, supermicron Na+ mass
label: BODY

text: concentrations were higher when leads were present (0.11 ± 0.03 μg m3) compared to when full sea ice
label: BODY

text: cover was present (0.03 μg m3). Unfortunately, no supermicron sampling periods of full sea ice coverage
label: BODY

text: with high wind speeds (>7 m s1) were present for comparison to periods of leads present with high
label: BODY

text: wind speeds.
label: BODY

text: When leads were present, supermicron Na+ mass concentrations were 4 and 10 times greater for periods with
label: BODY

text: moderate (0.11 ± 0.03 μg m3) and high (0.3 ± 0.1 μg m3) wind speeds, respectively, in comparison to low
label: BODY

text: wind speeds (0.03 ± 0.01 μg m3) (Figure 2a). This is consistent with wind-driven sea salt aerosol number
label: BODY

text: ﬂuxes from leads observed directly by Nilsson et al. [2001] and Leck et al. [2002]. Local leads, when observed
label: BODY

text: by the sea ice radar, are the most likely source for the wind-dependent supermicron Na+ mass observed in
label: BODY

text: this study, as the lifetime of supermicron aerosols in the boundary layer is typically < 12 h [Williams et al.,
label: BODY

text: 2002]. The short lifetime of these supermicron particles limits the distance from which the majority of these
label: BODY

text: particles could have originated, for the wind speeds observed, to a scale of a few hundred kilometers, which
label: BODY

text: would fall within the area of Arctic sea ice coverage in the winter-spring and for which the sea ice radar is
label: BODY

text: representative of ice fracturing conditions [Mahoney et al., 2014].
label: BODY

text: The highest supermicron Na+ mass concentrations are expected for open ocean and high wind speeds, as sea
label: BODY

text: salt aerosol production generally increases with increasing wind speed and fetch [Lewis and Schwartz, 2004].
label: BODY

text: While no supermicron particle sampling periods occurred for open ocean and low wind speeds, periods of
label: BODY

text: Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres
label: BODY

text: MAY ET AL.
label: BODY

text: ARCTIC SEA SALT AEROSOL
label: BODY

text: open ocean with moderate wind speeds showed supermicron Na+ mass concentrations (0.5 ± 0.1 μg m3)
label: BODY

text: 5 times greater than for periods when leads were present with moderate winds. Previously, sea salt
label: BODY

text: aerosol number ﬂuxes over leads were measured to be 10 times smaller than those over the open ocean
label: BODY

text: at similar wind speeds, an observation which was attributed to the smaller fetch and area of exposed
label: BODY

text: water [Leck et al., 2002; Nilsson et al., 2001]. Therefore, these long-term measurements show that while
label: BODY

text: a smaller source than open water, leads are a signiﬁcant wind-dependent source of supermicron sea salt
label: BODY

text: particle mass in the Arctic. The supermicron Na+ mass concentration for high wind speeds (0.3 μg m3)
label: BODY

text: was slightly lower than for periods of open ocean with moderate winds (0.5 ± 0.1 μg m3), contrary to
label: BODY

text: that expected based on the dependence of sea salt aerosol mass over open ocean on wind speed
label: BODY

text: [Lewis and Schwartz, 2004]. However, only one open ocean aerosol sampling period was characterized
label: BODY

text: by sustained high winds, imparting uncertainty in the trend that can be attributed to the small sample
label: BODY

text: size and natural variability in meteorological conditions that would impact sea salt aerosol concentra-
label: BODY

text: tions through deposition and marine boundary layer mixing [Lewis and Schwartz, 2004]. However, it is
label: BODY

text: important to note that despite these confounding factors there are statistically signiﬁcant trends
label: BODY

text: overall in the dependence of supermicron sea salt concentrations on local sea ice extent and local
label: BODY

text: wind speed.
label: BODY

text: Figure 2. Average mass concentrations of Na+ for the (a) supermicron (1–10 μm), (b) submicron particle (<1 μm) and
label: BODY

text: (c) total size ranges, and (d) the fraction of the total Na+ mass that was observed in the supermicron size range, separated
label: BODY

text: into nine bins based on local sea ice extent and wind speed. Sea ice extent categories include full ice, leads present, and open
label: BODY

text: water. Wind speed categoriesinclude low (<4 m s1), mid (4–7 m s1), and high (>7 m s1). All error bars were calculated as
label: BODY

text: the standard error of the mean, and the numbers above each category indicate the number of samples in that category.
label: BODY

text: Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres
label: BODY

text: MAY ET AL.
label: BODY

text: ARCTIC SEA SALT AEROSOL
label: BODY

text: There was no overall dependence of submicron (<1 μm) Na+ mass concentrations on local sea ice coverage
label: BODY

text: and wind speed (Figure 2b). Unlike supermicron Na+ mass concentrations, submicron Na+ mass concentra-
label: BODY

text: tions did not increase substantially when leads were present. The average submicron Na+ mass concentration
label: BODY

text: when leads were present was 0.25 ± 0.03 μg m3, compared to 0.21 ± 0.06 μg m3 when leads were not pre-
label: BODY

text: sent. In further contrast to supermicron Na+ mass concentrations, a wind speed dependence in submicron
label: BODY

text: Na+ mass concentration was not observed when leads were present (Figure 2b). In fact, open ocean periods
label: BODY

text: with low or moderate wind speeds resulted in the lowest observed submicron Na+ mass concentrations
label: BODY

text: (0.03 ± 0.02 μg m3 and 0.11 ± 0.03 μg m3, respectively). The lack of correlation of submicron Na+ mass
label: BODY

text: concentrations with local sea ice coverage and wind speed is most likely due to the longer atmospheric
label: BODY

text: residence time of submicron sea salt particles, compared to supermicron sea salt particles [Gong et al.,
label: BODY

text: 2002; Williams et al., 2002]. The shorter residence time of supermicron sea salt aerosol decreases the inﬂuence
label: BODY

text: of long-range transport, which signiﬁcantly inﬂuenced the observed submicron sea salt aerosol, as discussed
label: BODY

text: in section 3.2. The long-range transport of submicron sea salt aerosol produced from high-latitude open
label: BODY

text: ocean sources to the Arctic could therefore have a signiﬁcant inﬂuence on submicron Na+ mass concentra-
label: BODY

text: tions, as previously concluded [Barrie and Barrie, 1990; Barrie et al., 1994; Quinn et al., 2002; Sirois and Barrie,
label: BODY

text: 1999; Sturges and Barrie, 1988].
label: BODY

text: During periods of full sea ice cover and open ocean, submicron Na+ mass concentrations exhibited a
label: BODY

text: correlation with wind speed. For full sea ice periods, submicron Na+ mass concentrations increased from
label: BODY

text: low (0.19 ± 0.05 μg m3) and moderate (0.2 ± 0.1 μg m3) to high wind speed (0.3 μg m3), although the
label: BODY

text: increase from moderate to high wind speed was not statistically signiﬁcant, in part due to the availability of
label: BODY

text: only one sampling period at high wind speed for comparison (Figure 2b). Under full ice conditions, a non–wave
label: BODY

text: breaking source of Na+, as discussed in section 3.4, could potentially contribute, in addition to long-range
label: BODY

text: transport, as discussed in section 3.2. For open ocean periods, submicron Na+ showed a greater dependence
label: BODY

text: on local meteorology. Submicron Na+ mass concentrations increased from low (0.03 ± 0.01 μg m3) to moder-
label: BODY

text: ate (0.11 ± 0.03 μg m3) and high (0.2 ± 0.1 μg m3) wind speeds. However, the increase from moderate to
label: BODY

text: high wind speeds was not statistically signiﬁcant. The higher sea salt concentrations under these open ocean
label: BODY

text: conditions, along with the decrease in the fraction of aged submicron sea salt periods discussed in section 3.2,
label: BODY

text: suggests the inﬂuence of submicron sea salt production from local wind-driven wave breaking processes.
label: BODY

text: Overall, the supermicron fraction of the total Na+ mass concentration increased with decreasing sea ice cov-
label: BODY

text: erage and, in the presence of leads, increasing wind speed (Figures 2c and 2d). Supermicron Na+ mass con-
label: BODY

text: centrations comprised less than 20% of the total Na+ mass concentrations for periods with full sea ice cover
label: BODY

text: and with leads and low winds. In the presence of leads, the supermicron Na+ mass fraction increased with
label: BODY

text: increasing wind speed. At moderate wind speeds the supermicron Na+ mass concentration comprised
label: BODY

text: 40% of the total Na+ mass concentration for periods with leads, ~4 times greater than periods with leads
label: BODY

text: and low wind speeds. Then, for periods with leads and high wind speeds, the supermicron Na+ mass fraction
label: BODY

text: increased to 50% of the total Na+ mass concentration. Finally, the supermicron Na+ mass fraction was the
label: BODY

text: most dominant for periods with open ocean, comprising 60–80% of the total Na+ mass concentration. The
label: BODY

text: dependence of supermicron Na+ mass fraction on local sea ice coverage and wind speed highlights that
label: BODY

text: the supermicron sea salt aerosol population is more directly inﬂuenced by local sea ice coverage and wind
label: BODY

text: speed than the submicron sea salt aerosol population, as expected due to the longer atmospheric residence
label: BODY

text: time of submicron sea salt particles [Gong et al., 2002; Williams et al., 2002].
label: BODY

text: 3.2. Contributions of Aged Sea Salt Aerosol
label: BODY

text: Cl/Na+ molar ratios were calculated to investigate sea salt aerosol lifetime and chemical processing, a mea-
label: BODY

text: sure of the inﬂuence of long-range transport. Sea salt aerosol retains the Cl/Na+ molar ratio of seawater
label: BODY

text: (1.16) when introduced into the atmosphere [Keene et al., 1986]. This ratio is altered in the atmosphere
label: BODY

text: through the displacement of chlorine through reaction with acidic gases, such as H2SO4, or aqueous oxida-
label: BODY

text: tion of SO2(g) [Keene et al., 1998]. The extent of aging is thus dependent on atmospheric residence time, as
label: BODY

text: well as the original particle mass and acidic precursor concentrations in the atmosphere [Leck et al., 2002].
label: BODY

text: Previous work has shown that ﬁne sea salt aerosol (aerodynamic diameter < 2.5 μm) are more likely to have
label: BODY

text: greater chloride depletion than those of larger diameter coarse (aerodynamic diameter > 2.5 μm) sea salt
label: BODY

text: aerosol [Barrie et al., 1994; Hara et al., 2002; Leck et al., 2002]. In addition, previous work has shown that sea
label: BODY

text: Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres
label: BODY

text: MAY ET AL.
label: BODY

text: ARCTIC SEA SALT AEROSOL
label: BODY

text: salt aerosols exhibit greater depletion following polar sunrise when production of sulfuric acid from the
label: BODY

text: oxidation of SO2(g) occurs in the Arctic troposphere [Sirois and Barrie, 1999]. Using Cl/Na+ molar ratios
label: BODY

text: (Figure S1 in the supporting information), fractions of sampling periods dominated by “aged” sea salt were
label: BODY

text: calculated for each sea ice and wind speed category (Figure 3). Aged sea salt was deﬁned as having a Cl
label: BODY

text: enrichment factor < 0.75. Cl enrichment factor is determined by dividing the Cl/Na+ ratio of the aerosol
label: BODY

text: sample by the Cl/Na+ ratio of bulk seawater [Newberg et al., 2005]. Therefore, an enrichment factor < 0.75
label: BODY

text: corresponds to the depletion of 25% or more of Cl from sea salt aerosol and represents particles that have
label: BODY

text: undergone signiﬁcant atmospheric processing. Sampling periods with a Cl/Na+ enrichment factor > 0.75
label: BODY

text: were considered to consist primarily of “fresh” sea salt produced from local sources.
label: BODY

text: The average fraction of aged submicron sea salt periods (0.74 ± 0.07) across all local sea ice coverage and wind
label: BODY

text: speed categories was higher than the fraction of aged supermicron sea salt periods (0.39 ± 0.06) (Figure 3). The
label: BODY

text: median Cl/Na+ molar ratios for submicron and supermicron sea salt aerosol sampling periods also exhibited a
label: BODY

text: dependence on local sea ice coverage and wind speed (Figure S2). Overall, the median Cl/Na+ molar ratio of
label: BODY

text: submicron sea salt periods (0.62) was lower than the median Cl/Na+ molar ratio for supermicron sampling
label: BODY

text: periods (0.86) (Figure S2). This indicates that the atmospheric processing undergone by the submicron sea salt
label: BODY

text: resulted in a greater Cl depletion than the supermicron sea salt, as expected since smaller particles have a
label: BODY

text: longer residence time [Williams et al., 2002] and a higher surface area to volume ratio [McInnes et al., 1994].
label: BODY

text: Figure 3. The fraction of sampling periods with a Cl enrichment factor < 0.75, corresponding to aged sea salt for
label: BODY

text: (a) supermicron and (b) submicron size ranges, divided into categories based on sea ice conditions and wind speed,
label: BODY

text: similar to Figure 2.
label: BODY

text: Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres
label: BODY

text: MAY ET AL.
label: BODY

text: ARCTIC SEA SALT AEROSOL
label: BODY

text: The highest fractions (0.7–0.8) of aged sea salt sampling periods were observed when full sea ice cover with
label: BODY

text: low and moderate wind speeds were present, consistent with the lack of a local sea salt source (Figure 3). The
label: BODY

text: fractions of aged submicron and supermicron sea salt periods when leads or open ocean were present with
label: BODY

text: low wind speed were similarly high (0.6–0.8). That some of the highest fractions of aged sea salt were
label: BODY

text: observed under low wind conditions across all sea ice coverage categories indicates that the sea salt
label: BODY

text: observed during low wind periods, regardless of sea ice coverage, experienced increased atmospheric
label: BODY

text: processing, likely due to long-range transport.
label: BODY

text: For periods with leads present, the fraction of aged submicron and supermicron sea salt periods, respectively,
label: BODY

text: decreased from low (0.77 ± 0.06; 0.7 ± 0.2) to moderate (0.74 ± 0.05; 0.39 ± 0.09) to high wind speeds (0.64
label: BODY

text: ± 0.06; 0.1 ± 0.1), consistent with greater contributions from a wind-dependent local sea salt aerosol source
label: BODY

text: (Figure 3). However, this potential decrease in the fraction of aged submicron sea salt periods with increased
label: BODY

text: wind speed, when leads were present, was partly within error. When open ocean was present, the fraction of
label: BODY

text: aged submicron sea salt periods decreased, partly within error, with increasing wind speed (low wind
label: BODY

text: speed = 0.8 ± 0.2; moderate wind speed = 0.75 ± 0.07; high wind speed = 0.3 ± 0.1), again consistent with a
label: BODY

text: wind-dependent local sea salt aerosol source. These trends in sea salt aging are consistent with local sea salt
label: BODY

text: aerosol production increasing with decreasing local sea ice coverage and increasing wind speed. This further
label: BODY

text: supports wind-driven sea salt aerosol production, dominated by supermicron particles, from leads.
label: BODY

text: 3.3. Difference in Particle Production From Leads Versus Open Ocean
label: BODY

text: In addition to differences in particle lifetime between submicron and supermicron sea salt aerosol [Williams
label: BODY

text: et al., 2002], differences in the production mechanisms of submicron and supermicron sea salt aerosol from
label: BODY

text: leads likely also contributed to the observed trends in aged fractions and sea salt mass fractions. Leck et al.
label: BODY

text: [2002] and Nilsson et al. [2001] hypothesized that compared to open ocean production, ﬁlm drop particle pro-
label: BODY

text: duction from leads depends less on wind speed than jet drop particle production. As a result, the sea salt
label: BODY

text: aerosol size distribution over pack ice is dominated by a larger particle diameter lognormal mode at
label: BODY

text: ~2 μm, while over open ocean, a smaller particle diameter lognormal mode centered at 100 nm dominates
label: BODY

text: [Nilsson et al., 2001]. This is consistent with the lognormal size distribution of sea salt aerosol resulting from
label: BODY

text: ﬁlm and jet drops centered at ~100–200 nm and ~1–2 μm dry diameters, respectively, measured by O’Dowd
label: BODY

text: et al. [1997]. Thus, the larger contribution of fresh supermicron sea salt, compared to submicron sea salt,
label: BODY

text: observed during periods with leads and moderate to high winds (Figure 3) is consistent with the hypothesis
label: BODY

text: that jet drops are the dominant production mechanism of sea salt aerosol from leads. Additionally, the
label: BODY

text: increased presence of smaller particles over open ocean observed by Nilsson et al. [2001] is evident in this
label: BODY

text: study by the increased presence of fresh submicron sea salt during periods of open ocean and high wind
label: BODY

text: speeds (Figure 3). These results therefore suggest that the differences in wind-driven production of sea salt
label: BODY

text: aerosol from leads, compared to open ocean, shift the mass distribution of sea salt aerosol in the Arctic
label: BODY

text: toward larger sizes when leads are present. This could impact radiative forcing and cloud processes in the
label: BODY

text: Arctic as CCN efﬁciency is size dependent [Dusek et al., 2006].
label: BODY

text: 3.4. Non–Wave Breaking Particle Sources
label: BODY

text: Sea salt aerosol production from local leads and open ocean appears to be the dominant contributor to sea
label: BODY

text: salt mass concentrations in this study. However, submicron sea salt mass concentrations, sampled under con-
label: BODY

text: ditions where local sea salt aerosol production are not expected (e.g., 0.21 ± 0.06 μg m3 when full sea ice
label: BODY

text: cover was present), were equal to or greater than those from other categories where local sea salt production
label: BODY

text: are expected (e.g., 0.12 ± 0.03 μg m3 when open ocean was present). This suggests that there were sea salt
label: BODY

text: aerosol sources even when no exposed ocean surface was present (Figure 2b). Frost ﬂowers, highly saline ice
label: BODY

text: crystals grown on rapidly freezing open leads, are a potential source for wind-driven sea salt aerosol
label: BODY

text: production when no open ocean is present [Rankin et al., 2000]. However, as discussed in the supporting
label: BODY

text: information, the contribution from wind-blown frost ﬂowers to the measured sea salt aerosol concentrations
label: BODY

text: was likely minor as there were no full sea ice cover sampling periods with SO4
label: BODY

text: 2/Na+ molar ratios indicative
label: BODY

text: of frost ﬂowers (<0.02) (Figure S3) [Douglas et al., 2012]. In comparison, SO4
label: BODY

text: 2/Na+ molar ratios for fresh
label: BODY

text: seawater and fresh sea salt aerosol are ~0.06 [Keene et al., 2007]. However, sulfate isotope analysis would
label: BODY

text: be necessary to fully determine the inﬂuence of frost ﬂowers, as anthropogenic sulfates can mask the
label: BODY

text: sulfate depleted frost ﬂower sea salt [Norman et al., 1999; Seguin et al., 2014]. High winds can also loft
label: BODY

text: saline snow particles, which are suggested to form aerosols by sublimation [Lieb-Lappen and Obbard, 2015;
label: BODY

text: Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres
label: BODY

text: MAY ET AL.
label: BODY

text: ARCTIC SEA SALT AEROSOL
label: BODY

text: Yang et al., 2008]. The increase in submicron Na+ mass concentrations from low wind speed (0.19± 0.05μg m3),
label: BODY

text: to moderate wind speed (0.2 ± 0.1μg m3), to high wind speed (0.3 μg m3) for periods with full sea ice cover
label: BODY

text: was not also observed in the supermicron Na+ mass concentrations. Therefore, additional detailed ﬁeld
label: BODY

text: measurements of aerosol size and chemical composition are required to examine the potential size-dependent
label: BODY

text: production of aerosols from blowing snow. However, this increase in submicron Na+ mass concentration was
label: BODY

text: within error. In addition, the Cl/Na+ ratio of blowing snow in Barrow, AK, is expected to be similar to the ocean
label: BODY

text: water ratio [Jacobi et al., 2012], such that any fresh sea salt observed during full ice periods can potentially be
label: BODY

text: attributed to this source. Therefore, with less than 30% of the full sea ice cover submicron and supermicron
label: BODY

text: sampling periods characterized by fresh sea salt, the contribution from blowing snow production to the observed
label: BODY

text: Na+ mass concentrations is likely minor with transported sea salt aerosol representing a greater contribution.
label: BODY

text: 3.5. Seasonality of Sea Salt Aerosol Production
label: BODY

text: The Arctic sea ice coverage undergoes seasonal changes, with growth during winter, loss during summer,
label: BODY

text: and pack ice movement due to winds and currents [Mahoney et al., 2014]. In this study, particle sampling
label: BODY

text: periods with local full sea ice cover occurred during the months of November through June (Figure S4).
label: BODY

text: For these months, 11–36% and 0–25% of all submicron and supermicron particle sampling periods, respec-
label: BODY

text: tively, corresponded to local full sea ice coverage. For Barrow, AK, Quinn et al. [2002] previously observed a
label: BODY

text: winter maximum in submicron sea salt aerosol, attributed to long-range transport from high-latitude regions
label: BODY

text: of the Paciﬁc and Atlantic Oceans with seasonally high winds. This is consistent with the observations of the
label: BODY

text: highest fractions of aged sea salt and submicron Na+ mass concentrations during sampling periods with full
label: BODY

text: sea ice cover, suggesting that the winter sea salt aerosol population had the longest transport time from its
label: BODY

text: source. As expected, open ocean near Barrow was observed between July and November (Figure S4). The
label: BODY

text: minimum fractions of aged sea salt and maximum supermicron Na+ mass concentrations were observed
label: BODY

text: during these periods of local open ocean, suggesting the sea salt aerosol population during summer had
label: BODY

text: the shortest transport time from its source. The lower particle dry deposition velocity, and resulting longer
label: BODY

text: particle lifetime, over sea ice compared to over open ocean in the Arctic [Nilsson and Rannik, 2001] likely also
label: BODY

text: contributed to the higher fraction of aged sea salt and higher submicron Na+ mass concentrations during
label: BODY

text: sampling periods with full sea ice cover compared to periods of local open ocean. Nearby leads were
label: BODY

text: observed to be present between October and July and were the dominant sea ice category over the entire
label: BODY

text: study (Figure S3). Supermicron particle sampling periods with leads present comprised 50–91% of the
label: BODY

text: supermicron particle sampling periods months of October to July. Submicron particle sampling periods with
label: BODY

text: leads present comprised 64–91%, and 5%, of submicron particle sampling periods November to July, and
label: BODY

text: October, respectively. This suggests that sea salt aerosol production from leads currently impacts sea salt
label: BODY

text: aerosol mass concentrations, especially in the supermicron particle size range, in the Arctic atmosphere
label: BODY

text: throughout the majority of the year.
label: BODY

text: 4. Conclusions
label: BODY

text: This three-year study at Barrow, AK allowed a comprehensive investigation into the inﬂuences of sea ice cov-
label: BODY

text: erage and wind speed on sea salt mass concentrations in the coastal Arctic. Wind-driven production of sea
label: BODY

text: salt aerosol from leads contributes signiﬁcantly to sea salt aerosol mass concentrations in the Arctic, but to
label: BODY

text: a lesser extent than wind-driven production of sea salt aerosol from open ocean. This is consistent with pre-
label: BODY

text: vious short-term summertime number ﬂux measurements of sea salt aerosol over open leads, where sea salt
label: BODY

text: aerosol emissions were ~10 times smaller than the open ocean [Leck et al., 2002; Nilsson et al., 2001]. The inﬂu-
label: BODY

text: ence of sea salt aerosol production from open leads was most apparent in the supermicron size range, as evi-
label: BODY

text: denced by the strong dependence on wind speed of supermicron sea salt mass concentrations, which
label: BODY

text: increased by a factor of 10 from periods with low wind speed to periods with high wind speeds, when leads
label: BODY

text: were present. The increase in supermicron Na+ mass concentration from 0.035 ± 0.007 μg m3, when leads
label: BODY

text: were not present, to 0.12 ± 0.02 μg m3 when leads were present, provides further evidence of the inﬂuence
label: BODY

text: of sea salt aerosol production from leads. There was evidence of wind-driven submicron sea salt production
label: BODY

text: from local leads, but submicron sea salt, depleted in chloride, from long-range transport comprised the
label: BODY

text: majority (~70%) of the submicron sea salt mass. The inﬂuence of long-range transport was greatest when
label: BODY

text: local sea salt aerosol production would not be expected, including periods of low winds and full sea ice cover.
label: BODY

text: Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres
label: BODY

text: MAY ET AL.
label: BODY

text: ARCTIC SEA SALT AEROSOL
label: BODY

text: This improves our knowledge of complex atmosphere-sea ice feedbacks [Shepson et al., 2012]. Supermicron
label: BODY

text: sea salt aerosol production from leads could increase direct radiative forcing, as supermicron sea salt can con-
label: BODY

text: tribute signiﬁcantly to scattering in the remote marine boundary layer [Quinn et al., 1998]. This supermicron
label: BODY

text: sea salt aerosol could also impact indirect radiative forcing and cloud properties as giant CCN (2–10 μm),
label: BODY

text: which can induce the formation of larger cloud droplets and accelerate precipitation in the presence of smal-
label: BODY

text: ler particles [Yin et al., 2000]. The CCN response to supermicron sea salt aerosol produced from leads may be
label: BODY

text: reduced by the efﬁcient removal of large particles in the highly scavenging nature of the Arctic atmosphere,
label: BODY

text: particularly in summer [Browse et al., 2012]. Supermicron sea salt aerosol emissions from leads would also
label: BODY

text: increase the atmospheric condensation sink, which is predicted to suppress particle nucleation from
label: BODY

text: dimethyl sulﬁde and reduce total CCN concentrations [Browse et al., 2014]. Increased emissions of supermi-
label: BODY

text: cron sea salt aerosol from leads thus could play an important role in controlling the CCN response to changes
label: BODY

text: in sea ice [Browse et al., 2014]. Supermicron sea salt aerosol could also alter snowpack and atmospheric
label: BODY

text: halogen photochemistry, and therefore atmospheric oxidation [Simpson et al., 2005]. The impacts of wind-
label: BODY

text: driven production of sea salt aerosol from leads could be particularly evident in winter and early spring when
label: BODY

text: sea ice coverage is at its maximum and submicron sea salt mass concentrations are typically higher than
label: BODY

text: supermicron sea salt mass concentrations due to a lack of local open ocean source [Quinn et al., 2002].
label: BODY

text: Given decreasing multiyear sea ice extent and increasing ice fracturing [Stroeve et al., 2012], wind-driven
label: BODY

text: production of supermicron sea salt aerosol from leads could therefore increase the supermicron sea salt
label: BODY

text: aerosol mass fraction in the Arctic in the winter-spring, changing the annual contributions of sea salt aerosol
label: BODY

text: to the Arctic winter and early spring [Sirois and Barrie, 1999] may further increase the atmospheric sea salt
label: BODY

text: mass burden [Browse et al., 2012]. To fully understand the inﬂuence of sea salt aerosol produced from leads,
label: BODY

text: measurements of sea salt aerosol concentrations with higher time resolution must be combined with sea ice
label: BODY

text: coverage measurements that take into account a larger area. Furthermore, to understand the long-term
label: BODY

text: impacts of changing sea ice on the Arctic, decadal comparisons between sea ice conditions and sea salt
label: BODY

text: aerosol are necessary.
label: BODY
